The pandemic has decimated jobs in Korea's service sector, especially, and new data for April show just how big the impact has been.
According to the Korea Employment Information Service, the number of job postings on the recruiting site Worknet declined in April by 35.9 percent from a year ago to about 121-thousand.
Despite a rise in jobseekers of about 4 percent, this resulted in a decline in new hires of 23.6 percent.
The industries with the biggest decline in job postings were arts and sports at 57 percent, followed by hospitality at about 55 percent.
Educational services were down almost 50 percent as well.

That's nearly four times the amount borrowed during the same period last year.
As the outbreak continues in Korea, along with the economic impact, it's expected that the rise in bank loans will continue through the rest of the year.

To boost sluggish consumer spending, South Korea will hold a nationwide shopping festival for two weeks at the end of June.
Finance minister Hong Nam-ki said Thursday there'll be a variety of special sales online and discount coupons for use at small vendors and traditional markets.

"We expect this will help lift the burden on big and small distributors as well as local SMEs and small business owners who are struggling due to the pandemic."

And to support local auto parts firms, the government will set up a guarantee fund worth more than 4-hundred million U.S. dollars to prop up their sales.

"The government will protect the auto industry by supporting those with great technical capability but who struggle to thrive because their low credit rating prevents them from borrowing."

And to help carmakers, the government will buy around 9,5-hundred vehicles for its own use earlier than planned this year.
For the shipbuilding industry, the government will upgrade some 30 older vessels into eco-friendly ones.
They haven't forgotten sports either.
Loans for sports-related businesses will be expanded by around 16 million U.S. dollars.
The finance minister said he will announce plans early next month for revitalizing exports, including quarantine kits, in the upcoming policy direction for the second half of the year.
Kim Dami, Arirang News.
